attributes.comment:
I am writing to voice my objections concerning the raising of filing fees for
international adoptions.
Although many people adopt simply because they are big-hearted and love
children, there are many more people who adopt because of infertility and other
health related problems. Women are leaving having families later and later, and
fertility problems are on the rise. These are inescapable facts that dictate a likely
increase in the number of US citizens wanting to offer secure and happy homes to
children from many nations.
America leads the world in international adoption. My english wife would simply
not have the option to adopt, as we are doing, from China. We are a model to
other nations in this regard.
When people adopt, often, they are at the end of a very difficult road. They may
have suffered financially by paying for expensive medical treatments, or may have
simply decided upon first diagnosis of fertility problems, to adopt a child who may
not otherwise have had the chance of a secure and happy family. Whatever, their
rationale, the people who decide to adopt internationally are committed people
who are prepared to be judged, by the homestudy process, as good parents.
Surely those who submit to this process with such commitment and
determination are the people who should be most encouraged to raise sound,
productive and happy citizens?
Why, then, should they be penalised by further fees?
I am writing to voice my extreme displeasure at the raising of the barrier, and
fervently hope that the already heavy fees remain unchanged.
Yours sincerely
TA Hennard
Secondary Principal, International School of Stavanger
attributes.title: Comment Submitted by Tommie Hennard
